# About {#about}

The motivation of our research is to understand climate risks and reduce uncertainties in regional predictions and projections of extreme weather and climate events. This requires an improved causal understanding of the physical drivers and consequences of extreme events. Our research includes several sub-aspects:

# Research {#research}
This is the research section.

<div class="research-row">

<div class="research-feature">
<a href="research/teleconnections/index.qmd">
<img src="research/teleconnections/teleconnections.png" alt="Teleconnections" class="research-image">
</a>
<h3 class="research-text">Teleconnections</h3>
<p>One focus is better to understand the underlying large-scale physical drivers and causal mechanisms of extreme events and to quantify these so-called teleconnections. In particular, we are researching the stratospheric polar vortex, the global impacts of Arctic sea ice retreat, and how tropical and extratropical teleconnections interact to drive extreme weather.</p>
</div>

<div class="research-feature">
<a href="research/detection_and_attribution/index.qmd">
<img src="research/detection_and_attribution/DA.png" alt="Detection and Attribution" class="research-image">
</a>
<h3 class="research-text">Detection and Attribution</h3>
<p>One goal is to identify relevant extreme events and trends that have strong environmental and societal impacts, and to understand the contribution of humans activities in these. For example, we study heat waves in Europe, extreme cold spells in the US, or precipitation and droughts in the Mediterranean region.</p>
</div>
